Every time costs went up, the French and British governments just kept throwing in more cash. They knew theyâ€™d probably never get their money back. With limited seats, few orders, and high production costs, it was obvious the project would never turn a profit.  

When old government documents were released, they showed that officials knew the investment "could not stand on normal economic grounds."  

So why did smart government leaders keep pouring money into a sinking ship? One big reason is something called â€œsunk-cost bias.â€  

Sunk-cost bias is when you keep investing time, money, or energy into something just because youâ€™ve already put so much into it.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The Concorde jet exemplifies how sunk-cost bias can lead to continued investment in a failing project despite clear evidence of its financial impracticality.
